titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Peter Goin photographs, 1987-2006 and undated RL.00459
titlestmt.author: Paula Jeannet Mangiafico, Matthew Warren

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Peter Goin photographs
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: Collection consists of photographs by Peter Goin on the theme of the interactions and the connections between people and the natural world, and the way people manage, perceive, and represent "nature." The images depict altered and artificial landscapes featuring beaches, canals, farm fields, rivers, prescribed burns and reforestation sites, zoos, an abandoned town, and other places. They were shot in various locations, predominantly in North and South Carolina and Virginia, but also in Alabama, Georgia, central Florida, Arizona, California, Tennessee, and Nevada. The project resulted in a book, Humanature (1996) and an exhibit. Image formats include 16x20 inch exhibit-quality color prints, accompanied by negatives, black-and-white work prints, and book illustration prints. Research, correspondence, and other publication materials are also included in the collection. Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts, Duke University.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research; however, photocopying is restricted. Access to original negatives only by permission of curator of Archive of Documentary Arts.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Peter Goin photographs, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Peter Goin photographs were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase from 1992-1994; other materials received as a gift in 2014 and 2016.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Matthew Warren, December 2011. Updated with new addition, 2015 and 2016.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection chiefly consists of photographs by Peter Goin on the theme of the interactions and the connections between people and the natural world, and the way people manage, perceive, and represent "nature." The exhibit-quality color prints (16x20 inches) and black-and-white work prints (chiefly 8x10) feature images taken Goin from 1991-1992 while he was Artist-In-Residence at the Center for Documentary Studies at Duke University. They depict altered and artificial landscapes such as beaches, canals, farm fields, rivers and dams, managed forests, a scale model of a river, zoos, an abandoned town (Ellenton, S.C.), and other places. In these settings, people can be seen replanting trees, building ditches, hunting, or simply surveying their surroundings. Other formats include negatives, two slides, and book illustration prints. The collection also includes research, correspondence, publicity, and other materials deriving from the book Humanature.

The images were shot in various locations, predominantly in North and South Carolina and Virginia, but also in Alabama, Georgia, central Florida, Arizona, California, and Tennessee. Locations in North Carolina include Durham, the NC Zoological Park, Duke Forest, the Carnivore Preservation Trust, Outer Banks beaches, the Chatooga and Nantahala Rivers, and the Appalachian mountains near Highlands. There is also one image from Nevada. A selection was published in Goin's book, Humanature, published by University of Texas Press in 1996, and the project also generated a traveling exhibit of the same name.

A group of copy prints included in the collection were used illustrate Goin's book. These are historic images from the 1930s through the 1980s, many taken to document the work of state-run programs. As with Goinâs own work, they also show human-altered landscapes such as reforestation sites, canals, beach erosion replanting sites, and others. A few images appear to be from the 1950s and are of schoolchildren in Aiken, South Carolina. Other locations include Durham, N.C.âs Duke Forest, the Colorado River, beaches, and western deserts.
Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts, Duke University.

arrangement.head: Collection Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized in series by format: Negatives, Photographic Prints, and Papers.

did.unittitle: Negatives, 1991-1992 and undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains a mostly complete collection of 4x5 inch negatives used to create the work and exhibit prints. While a large majority of the negatives have corresponding black-and-white and color prints, about ten have no prints. The full text and identifying numbers for all captions as well as additional information about the project can be found in Goin's notebook pages housed in this collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Access to original negatives only by permission of the Curator of the Archive of Documentary Arts.

did.unittitle: Negatives, 4x5 inch, front matter illustrations for Humanature, undated
Photographic prints

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Chiefly consists of exhibit and work prints produced by Peter Goin for the project "Humanature." Corresponding negative numbers are marked on reverse side of prints. There are several prints with identification numbers CB31 and CG32. Original captions have been retained; ellipses indicate additional text in long captions that has not been included. The full text for all captions as well as additional information about the project can be found in the notebook pages housed in the Papers Series.
The series is concluded by a group of 81 copy prints and other items labeled as "front-matter illustrations" for the book, Humanature.

did.unittitle: Work prints, black-and-white, circa 1991-1992

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The most complete set of printed images with captions is found in this subseries of black-and-white 8x10 inch work prints used by Goin to select frames for larger exhibit prints. All captions are original. Ellipses indicate text found in very long captions that was not included here.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Color prints measure 16x20 inches and are marked on reverse with corresponding negative numbers. Captions for images found only in the color series and not in the black-and-white prints series are written out below. Otherwise, a complete itemized caption list is found in the black-and-white work prints series.

Book illustration copy prints for Humanature, 1990s and undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Label on original box refers to "front-matter illustrations." They are presented in a mix of 8x10 and 5x7 inch glossy prints, 5x7 inch older prints, a smaller color print, and two color slides. Some prints have captions, illustration numbers, and negative numbers; a few have editing instructions. Scenes are of human-altered landscapes from the 1930s to the 1980s.

did.unittitle: Copy prints and other items, black-and-white and color
Papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Houses pages from a notebook of information assembled by the photographer, which describes the project "Humanature," and is accompanied by a full list of captions. Captions given in the section below are taken from notebook, and represent images from Humanature that are not in the collection.
